author: By Shannon Doyne and Michael Gonchar
title: How Are You Feeling About Missing Prom?
description: Millions of students are not having the end of school year they thought they would. What spring traditions and special events have been lost or transformed at your school?
content: In “All Dressed Up, With No Prom to Go To,” Jazmine Hughes writes that “for students in the class of 2020, the Covid-19 crisis arrived just as they were receiving college acceptance letters, dreaming about new jobs, gearing up to leave high school behind — and making plans for prom, which, for most students, has been canceled.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Austria?
description: Can you find Austria on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of nearly 9 million people?
content: Can you find Austria on a map? What else do you know about this European nation with a population of nearly 9 million people?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills, a Craftsman house in Santa Barbara and a midcentury-modern retreat in Ojai.
content: This cottage-style home in the Hollywood Hills is a 10-minute drive from the nightclubs and music venues of Hollywood, as well as the cafes and shopping of quieter Studio City. It is a five-minute drive from the base of the hiking trail at Runyon Canyon Park, one of the city’s most popular outdoor exercise spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford
title: Coronavirus, Antibody Tests, Nova Scotia: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here's what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Competitive Marble Racing Finds Fans in a World Missing Sports’
description: In this lesson, students learn about the joy and escapism many are finding in this pastime.
content: Featured Article: “Competitive Marble Racing Finds Fans in a World Missing Sports”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Turn Nearly Anything Into a Meal With This Simple Sauce
description: Salmon stars in this tonnato, an extremely simple sauce traditionally made with tuna, that lifts rich meat and crisp raw vegetables alike.
content: Next time you head to the market to restock your canned fish, here’s something to consider: Throw some salmon into your cart along with all that tuna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Noach Dear, Combative Brooklyn Councilman and Judge, Dies at 66
description: In pursuing his constituents’ Orthodox Jewish agenda, he opposed abortion rights and legislation to ban discrimination against gay people.
content: Noach Dear, who served nearly two decades on the New York City Council as an outlier, advocating on behalf of the conservative agenda of his Orthodox Jewish constituents in Brooklyn while defending himself against accusations of conflicts of interest, died on Sunday in Brooklyn. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Luis Sepúlveda, Chilean Writer Exiled by Pinochet, Dies at 70
description: His best-known work was “The Old Man Who Read Love Stories.” Mr. Sepúlveda was among the first people in Spain hospitalized with the new coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Frustrated by Lack of Coronavirus Tests, Maryland Got 500,000 From South Korea
description: Facing shortages, Gov. Larry Hogan and his wife, Yumi Hogan, negotiated with suppliers in South Korea to obtain the kits. “It should not have been this difficult,” he said.
content: When President Trump told governors that they needed to step up their efforts to secure medical supplies, Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland took the entreaty seriously and negotiated with suppliers in South Korea to obtain coronavirus test kits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Joy of Paper Flowers
description: Field guides and seed catalogs comfort me in winter. Could they help me through the pandemic, too?
content: NASHVILLE — My mother spent every winter thumbing through seed catalogs and gardening books. “What Flower Is That?,” an encyclopedic volume by an Australian writer named Stirling Macoboy, was her favorite. Mom fell asleep by eight every night, even with all the lights on in the house, even with my father and all three of us kids watching television in the big bed beside her. But she got up before dawn every morning, long before the rest of us, and if I ever happened to wake up early myself, I could find her on the living room sofa with “What Flower Is That?” open in her lap. It contains more than a thousand color photos of flowers from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: How Poor Diet Contributes to Coronavirus Risk
description: Improving our metabolic health could help ward off future medical, economic and social calamities from whatever pathogen next comes down the pike.
content: Of the many heartbreaking stories I’ve read or heard during this ghastly pandemic, one stands out as especially distressing, almost criminal. The headline, on Page 1 of The Times on April 12, read: “Empty Shelves, But Farms Put Food to Waste — Milk, Eggs and Produce Buried and Dumped.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky, Catherine Porter and Ian Austen
title: Police Seek Motive for Canada Killing Spree by Denture Fitter
description: Gabriel Wortman was believed to have killed at least 18 people in a 12-hour rampage that was the country’s worst mass shooting.
content: MONTREAL — He appeared obsessed with the police and owned eerily realistic copies of police uniforms and a homemade replica squad car. He fitted dentures for customers, many of them elderly admirers of his comforting bedside manner. He had a childhood fascination with air guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Harry and Meghan Cut Off U.K. Tabloids
description: A letter to four major newspapers criticized coverage as “distorted, false, or invasive beyond reason.” It was the latest twist in the couple’s poisonous relationship with some news outlets.
content: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have all but vanished from the headlines in a world consumed by a catastrophic pandemic. But that did not stop the newly independent couple from notifying four leading British tabloid publishers on Sunday that they would no longer deal with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: How Abortion, Guns and Church Closings Made Coronavirus a Culture War
description: Flattening the curve is now one of the most contentious issues in politics.
content: This is what it looks like when a pandemic collides with the culture wars in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Dispute Over Virus Testing Delays Deal on Aid to Small Businesses and Hospitals
description: Democrats are insisting that the legislation require the Trump administration to establish a national testing strategy, but the president wants states to take responsibility.
content: WASHINGTON — A dispute between Democrats and the White House over how to handle coronavirus testing emerged on Monday as one of the most significant sticking points as negotiators struggled to finalize a nearly $500 billion bipartisan agreement to replenish a loan program for small businesses and provide more funding for hospitals and testing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Christina Goldbaum
title: ‘The Worst-Case Scenario’: New York’s Subway Faces Its Biggest Crisis
description: The nation’s largest urban transit system is seeking billions more in federal aid but may have to consider drastic measures, including postponing critical improvements.
content: The New York City subway system rebounded from the 1970s, when the city teetered on the edge of bankruptcy, crumbling cars routinely broke down and rampant crime scared riders away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Neil MacFarquhar
title: Coronavirus Devastates Detroit Police, From the Chief on Down
description: The force reeled as hundreds of officers were infected or quarantined, and an initial drop in crime suddenly reversed with a spate of shootings.
content: DETROIT — At the “Police and Pancakes” breakfast sponsored by the Ninth Precinct on Detroit’s east side, some 90 uniformed officers, activists and students mingled inside a community center. They squeezed into line to reach a long table where four aluminum chafing dishes brimmed with scrambled eggs, Danishes, fruit and, of course, pancakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Can You Make Money in Live Comedy Right Now? Some Producers Say Yes
description: Experiments with online business models have led in at least one case to more tickets sold. And as the trappings change, the nature of the humor seems to be changing, too.
content: No one in live comedy is thrilled about moving shows online. “Doing standup without an audience is like sex without an orgasm,” quipped Felicia Madison, the booker for West Side Comedy Club. “Why bother?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Planning for the Hotel Opening, Coronavirus Be Damned
description: A handful of hotels are moving ahead with scheduled openings, whether or not the guests will arrive.
content: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Take YouTube’s Dangers Seriously
description: The website’s features can lead people unwittingly to scary places.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Planning for the Hotel Opening, Coronavirus Be Damned
description: A handful of hotels are moving ahead with scheduled openings, whether or not the guests will arrive.
content: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kendra Pierre-Louis
title: Climate Crash Course Part 2: How do scientists know what they know?
description: To answer the next big question, Kendra Peirre-Louis explains how redundancy helps scientists recreate temperatures from years, decades and centuries past.
content: To answer the next big question, Kendra Peirre-Louis explains how redundancy helps scientists recreate temperatures from years, decades and centuries past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Climate Crash Course Part 1: How bad is climate change now?
description: From the Times’s Climate Desk’s series that addresses big questions. From Henry Fountain: “The only real debates are over how fast and how far the climate will change, and what society should do.”
content: From the Times’s Climate Desk’s series that addresses big questions. From Henry Fountain: “The only real debates are over how fast and how far the climate will change, and what society should do.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump, Head of Government, Leans Into Antigovernment Message
description: With his poll numbers fading after a rally-around-the-leader bump, the president is stoking protests against stay-at-home orders.
content: First he was the self-described “wartime president.” Then he trumpeted the “total” authority of the federal government. But in the past few days, President Trump has nurtured protests against state-issued stay-at-home orders aimed at curtailing the spread of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Glanz and Thomas Nilsen
title: A Deep-Diving Sub. A Deadly Fire. And Russia’s Secret Undersea Agenda.
description: Few want to talk about how 14 sailors met their deaths on a Russian engineering marvel. Fewer still want to talk about what they were doing off Norway’s waters.
content: OFF THE COAST OF NORWAY — There could hardly have been a more terrifying place to fight a fire than in the belly of the Losharik, a mysterious deep-diving Russian submarine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: How Abortion, Guns and Church Closings Made Coronavirus a Culture War
description: Flattening the curve is now one of the most contentious issues in politics.
content: This is what it looks like when a pandemic collides with the culture wars in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu and Christina Goldbaum
title: ‘The Worst-Case Scenario’: New York’s Subway Faces Its Biggest Crisis
description: The nation’s largest urban transit system is seeking billions more in federal aid but may have to consider drastic measures, including postponing critical improvements.
content: The New York City subway system rebounded from the 1970s, when the city teetered on the edge of bankruptcy, crumbling cars routinely broke down and rampant crime scared riders away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll, Azi Paybarah, Jacob Meschke and Elaine Chen
title: 11 Numbers That Show How the Coronavirus Has Changed N.Y.C.
description: Unemployment has skyrocketed, but so has the size of the city’s volunteer pool and the number of people fostering animals. One month into the shutdown, the city is as complex as it ever was.
content: New York City has never looked so unlike itself. Deserted streets and vacant stores. Essential workers taking to lonely subways. Mandatory face coverings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky, Catherine Porter and Ian Austen
title: Police Seek Motive for Canada Killing Spree by Denture Fitter
description: Gabriel Wortman was believed to have killed at least 18 people in a 12-hour rampage that was the country’s worst mass shooting.
content: MONTREAL — He appeared obsessed with the police and owned eerily realistic copies of police uniforms and a homemade replica squad car. He fitted dentures for customers, many of them elderly admirers of his comforting bedside manner. He had a childhood fascination with air guns.

title: Harry and Meghan Cut Off U.K. Tabloids
description: A letter to four major newspapers criticized coverage as “distorted, false, or invasive beyond reason.” It was the latest twist in the couple’s poisonous relationship with some news outlets.
content: LONDON — Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, have all but vanished from the headlines in a world consumed by a catastrophic pandemic. But that did not stop the newly independent couple from notifying four leading British tabloid publishers on Sunday that they would no longer deal with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic and Hiroko Masuike
title: Oil, Singapore, Nova Scotia: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Robert Loomis, Old-School Editor of Big-Name Books, Dies at 93
description: He wielded his pencil at Random House for more than 50 years, nurturing the work of Maya Angelou, William Styron and other literary lights.
content: Robert Loomis, an editor who bloodlessly transformed embryonic manuscripts by a pantheon of 20th-century American authors into award-winning and best-selling books, died on Sunday in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Says He Will Halt Immigration; States Start to Reopen Businesses
description: South Carolina eases some lockdown restrictions, and Georgia and Tennessee will follow suit. Cases at an Ohio prison surge, and oil prices plummet.
content: President Trump said on Monday that he intended to close the United States to people trying to immigrate into the country to live and work, a drastic move that he said would protect American workers from foreign competition once the nation’s economy began to recover from the shutdown caused by the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Trump Exceptionalism
description: What happened to President Trump’s approval ratings?
content: A few weeks ago, as the president received some of the highest marks of his presidency, we wrote about a “Trump bump.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Peter Beard, “The End of the Game”
description: Mr. Beard’s 1965 landmark work on Africa was written and shot while working for a warden in the Tsavo East National Park in Kenya.
content: Mr. Beard’s 1965 landmark work on Africa was written and shot while working for a warden in the Tsavo East National Park in Kenya.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The ‘Open the Country’ Protesters
description: Readers discuss whether it’s time to begin lifting the coronavirus restrictions, and the president’s encouragement of right-wing protests.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maitreesh Ghatak, Xavier Jaravel and Jonathan Weigel
title: The World Has a $2.5 Trillion Problem. Here’s How to Solve It.
description: Poor countries are going to be decimated by the coronavirus. They need a serious rescue package.
content: The coronavirus has not yet exploded in the developing world, but poor countries are already suffering from the pandemic. Their economies have been battered by lockdowns, falling commodity prices, declining remittances, and unprecedented capital flight. Some $100 billion has fled emerging markets since January, five times more than in the 2008 crash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Levitan
title: The Infection That’s Silently Killing Coronavirus Patients
description: This is what I learned during 10 days of treating Covid pneumonia at Bellevue Hospital.
content: I have been practicing emergency medicine for 30 years. In 1994 I invented an imaging system for teaching intubation, the procedure of inserting breathing tubes. This led me to perform research into this procedure, and subsequently teach airway procedure courses to physicians worldwide for the last two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damon Winter
title: The Great American Divide
description: The coronavirus crisis has underscored our enduring inequalities in race, wealth and health.
content: You don’t have to look hard to find inequality in America. For the past several weeks I have been sheltering with my family in Central New York, where even among the rolling hills and sweeping expanses of farmland, the vast divide between the haves and have-nots is as plainly visible as it is in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Istanbul Death Toll Hints Turkey Is Hiding a Wider Coronavirus Calamity
description: Istanbul recorded 2,100 more deaths over recent years between March and April, The Times found, suggesting a hidden toll.
content: ISTANBUL — For weeks President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has presented Turkey’s performance in handling the coronavirus as one of the world’s most successful, as he maintained strict control over information about the outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Help! My Mask Fogs My Glasses
description: Health workers have a few tricks for solving this vexing problem, but it will take trial and error to find the one that works for you.
content: In many parts of the world, nearly two out of three people wear corrective eyewear. And lately, many of us have the same complaint: Wearing a mask makes our glasses fog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Breastfeeding May Lower Risk of Ovarian Cancer
description: Nursing for three months was associated with an 18 percent lower risk of ovarian cancer, and for more than a year with a 34 percent lower risk.
content: For new mothers, breastfeeding, even for a few months, is associated with a significant decrease in the risk for ovarian cancer years down the road, a review of studies has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Palmer
title: More Puzzles to Pass the Time
description: An expanded space for games in our print edition is intended to challenge your brain but ease your mind.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: What It’s Like Self-Isolating in a Studio Apartment
description: One-room dwellings have long been part of New York City’s hustle and hope. But how about when there’s nowhere else to go?
content: Paris has its garrets; London, its bedsits. In New York, it’s the studio apartment — and its grittier cousin, the tenement railroad flat — that has sheltered generations of strivers and makers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Stop Airing Trump’s Briefings!
description: The media is allowing disinformation to appear as news.
content: Around this time four years ago, the media world was all abuzz over an analysis by mediaQuant, a company that tracks what is known as “earned media” coverage of political candidates. Earned media is free media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: The Case of the Disappearing Exoplanet
description: Fomalhaut b was one of the first planets around another star to be directly imaged by telescopes. Some astronomers now say it was a cloud of asteroid debris.
content: Humanity’s growing tally of exoplanets — worlds seen orbiting other stars — stands at 4,151. Most were found indirectly, as they passed in front of their stars and cast a telltale shadow, or as they caused their star to wobble as they swung around it. Only 50 have been directly imaged through a telescope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Singapore Seemed to Have Coronavirus Under Control, Until Cases Doubled
description: The spread suggests that it is unrealistic for the United States, Europe and the rest of the world to return to the way they were anytime soon, even if viral curves appear to flatten.
content: Singapore did almost everything right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye, Andrew Jacobs, Jo Becker and Tim Arango
title: Doctors and Governors Vie for Masks in Cloak-and-Dagger Deals
description: Despite plans to reopen states, equipment to protect workers from the coronavirus remains in high demand. “The need for an organized, equitable distribution system is dire,” a doctor said.
content: It was a stealth transaction, arranged through “someone who knew someone who knew someone,” taking place at an undisclosed location in an unnamed mid-Atlantic state. The getaway vehicles were disguised as food service delivery trucks, and they mapped out separate routes back to Massachusetts to avoid detection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Matthew Goldstein and Jeanna Smialek
title: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
description: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal policymakers have rushed to backstop nearly every corner of the financial system as the coronavirus exacts a bruising toll on the U.S. economy. But there is growing concern that a critical corner of the housing industry has been overlooked, putting mortgage companies in a precarious position as millions of borrowers delay payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurora Almendral
title: On Pandemic’s Front Lines, Nurses From Half a World Away
description: Nurses from the Philippines and other developing countries have long made up for shortages in Western nations. Now they are risking their lives.
content: MANILA — There were seven nurses in the Buendia family. One of them, Jhoanna Mariel Buendia, got a call from the Philippines on March 28, just before the start of her shift at an intensive care unit in a British hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The International Herald Tribune
title: 1970: Jet’s Engine Explodes, Injuring 23
description: A Scandinavian Airlines jet with 75 people aboard caught fire and burned when an engine exploded during takeoff.
content: ROME, April 19 (UPI) — A Scandinavian Airlines jet bound from Tokyo to Copenhagen with 75 persons aboard caught fire and burned today when an engine exploded during takeoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Klass, M.D
title: How Parents Can Support College Students’ Online Learning
description: I asked students what parents could do to help them finish a semester that was never supposed to go this way.
content: I’ve been in a lot of Zoom “classrooms” over the past month, teaching, talking with college students, some sent home from study abroad and continuing on with the language lessons that made so much more sense in another country, or with the art history discussions that were supposed to build to a museum trip, others who should have been in a big lecture hall or a cozy seminar room (remember big lecture halls and cozy seminar rooms?) in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: A Hill of Beans
description: Pair them with rice, or with pasta, or as part of an avocado salad, or forgo them all together, and head to the grill.
content: Good morning. I’m lucky to have a grill out back, and it’s been put to good use of late: baby back ribs and beer-can chicken and hot slaw and glazed carrots and grilled peaches straight from the jar. Now it’s back to the uncomfortable chair and the rickety desk, my makeshift office a step from the bed, with sardines on crackers with a swipe of mayonnaise for lunch, and late dinners to follow: rice and beans; beans and rice; rice on beans (above). I play the legume catalog as if it were a binder of standards these days. I’m the Bucky Pizzarelli of beans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Ottolenghi’s Test Kitchen Is Closed. But the Recipes Keep Coming.
description: Away from their small North London hub, a six-member team still finds a way to share recipes, and feed loved ones.
content: LONDON — Before our world was turned on its head so abruptly only a few (very long) weeks ago, the center of my universe outside home was my test kitchen. A modest space underneath a railway arch in Camden, north London, it doubles as a cooking hub and an office. Six of us spend most of our time there, thinking up ideas, testing dishes repeatedly and talking about them ad infinitum. It’s where concepts take shape and plans for future projects — recipes, articles, books and restaurant dishes, bagged products, cakes and treats of any shape or form — are developed. The general spirit of things to come is dreamed up in the test kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: When Crocodiles Once Dived Like Dolphins and Whales
description: They didn’t have blowholes, but an ancient lineage of crocodilians returned to the oceans in a manner similar to some marine mammals.
content: Some 400 million years ago, animals emerged from the ocean for the first time and began to thrive on land. But after eons of evolutionary experimentation, some lineages peaced out of the terrestrial world and embraced a full-time life at sea again. While whales and dolphins are among the best known marine creatures to follow this path, it turns out some ancient relatives of modern crocodiles, called thalattosuchians, took the same aquatic turn while dinosaurs roamed the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholette Zeliadt
title: What Causes Autism?
description: From genes to environment, experts have identified several factors that influence a child’s chance of having autism. But risk is not destiny, they say.
content: Melissa Smith had always wanted to have three children. Last April, as she was trying to get pregnant for a third time, she learned her youngest child was autistic. After she got over the initial shock, the news came as a relief. “I had known for months that something was wrong,” she said. “To finally have an answer, and to have a diagnosis that would afford us solutions and therapy to help, was definitely a relief.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Abigail Thernstrom, Scholarly Foe of Affirmative Action, Dies at 83
description: She supported civil rights, but later, with her husband, Stephan, concluded that colorblind policies worked better than preferential treatment.
content: Abigail Thernstrom, a social scientist whose colorblind remedies for racial disparities in educational achievement, voting and employment elevated her from a former red-diaper baby into a leading skeptic of affirmative action programs, died on April 10 in Arlington, Va. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: Climate Crash Course Part 4: How do we stop fossil fuel emissions?
description: Halfway through our climate crash course, Brad Plumer lays out a rough game plan for the enormous task of zeroing out carbon emissions.
content: Halfway through our climate crash course, Brad Plumer lays out a rough game plan for the enormous task of zeroing out carbon emissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sunnie R. Clahchischiligi
title: Nowhere Is Remote Anymore
description: Coronavirus in the Navajo Nation exposes underlying vulnerabilities.
content: ALBUQUERQUE — Last month, when the first two confirmed cases of the coronavirus were announced in the Navajo Nation, I packed a bag and returned to the safest place I knew: home. I joined my parents to visit Yellow Rock Point on the Utah side of the reservation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘Westworld’ Season 3, Episode 6 Recap: The Man in White
description: The Man in Black finds a new purpose as the lines are sharpened for a colossal showdown.
content: With only two episodes left in the season, “Westworld” spent this week’s putting all the pieces in place for a mix-and-match battle royale between humans and hosts, hosts and hosts, and humans and humans. There was still the usual chatter over free will, mostly in a metaphysical group therapy session where William confronts his father-in-law and various incarnations of himself, but the episode was mostly about arranging the pieces on the board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Matthew Goldstein and Jeanna Smialek
title: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
description: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal policymakers have rushed to backstop nearly every corner of the financial system as the coronavirus exacts a bruising toll on the U.S. economy. But there is growing concern that a critical corner of the housing industry has been overlooked, putting mortgage companies in a precarious position as millions of borrowers delay payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Landowners in Montana Superfund Fight
description: Landowners may not sue the Atlantic Richfield Company to force it to do more than a federal cleanup plan requires unless the Environmental Protection Agency consents, the court ruled.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court dealt a setback on Monday to roughly 100 Montana residents who sought to sue Atlantic Richfield Company to help them restore property contaminated by arsenic and lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: When Crocodiles Once Dived Like Dolphins and Whales
description: They didn’t have blowholes, but an ancient lineage of crocodilians returned to the oceans in a manner similar to some marine mammals.
content: Some 400 million years ago, animals emerged from the ocean for the first time and began to thrive on land. But after eons of evolutionary experimentation, some lineages peaced out of the terrestrial world and embraced a full-time life at sea again. While whales and dolphins are among the best known marine creatures to follow this path, it turns out some ancient relatives of modern crocodiles, called thalattosuchians, took the same aquatic turn while dinosaurs roamed the planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: The Small-Space Workout Challenge
description: If your home isn’t that big, finding a place to exercise while you’re confined there may seem nearly impossible. Here’s what the experts suggest.
content: If you’re used to hitting the gym or running in an urban park or on city sidewalks, being ordered to stay at home has required a radical rethinking of your workout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Novak Djokovic Expresses Resistance to Coronavirus Vaccine
description: Though Djokovic, in an online chat, expressed concerns about having to accept a vaccination in order to travel for the tennis tour, he said in a follow-up statement that he would keep an open mind.
content: Novak Djokovic, the world’s No. 1 men’s tennis player, caused a stir with comments over the weekend suggesting he would have a difficult decision to make if receiving a coronavirus vaccine became mandatory to compete on the tennis circuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: The U.S. Tried to Teach China a Lesson About the Media. It Backfired.
description: American journalists were showing the world the devastating effects of China’s botched response to the coronavirus. Now, many have been kicked out.
content: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is better known for yelling at journalists than consoling them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick J. Lyons
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Disputes over testing availability and strategy in the U.S. impeded progress on several fronts.
content: When can stay-at-home orders be relaxed safely? Not until we get much more testing, many state governors say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Why Don’t You Just Die!’ Review: Attempted Murder, but Make It Comedy
description: Kirill Sokolov’s debut feature is a bloody and often hilarious exercise in excruciating harm-doing among mendacious people.
content: There’s a sense in which this Russian film, a raucous, violent comedy of vengeance written and directed by Kirill Sokolov, may immediately feel familiar — at least if you’re a genre film aficionado. Its early shots show our hero, so to speak — Matvey (Aleksandr Kuznetsov), a young fellow with an unusually shaped nose wearing a sweatshirt with a Batman symbol on it — standing outside of an apartment, slightly nervous, and not without reason. He’s holding a new-looking steel hammer behind his back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholette Zeliadt
title: What Causes Autism?
description: From genes to environment, experts have identified several factors that influence a child’s chance of having autism. But risk is not destiny, they say.
content: Melissa Smith had always wanted to have three children. Last April, as she was trying to get pregnant for a third time, she learned her youngest child was autistic. After she got over the initial shock, the news came as a relief. “I had known for months that something was wrong,” she said. “To finally have an answer, and to have a diagnosis that would afford us solutions and therapy to help, was definitely a relief.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Abigail Thernstrom, Scholarly Foe of Affirmative Action, Dies at 83
description: She supported civil rights, but later, with her husband, Stephan, concluded that colorblind policies worked better than preferential treatment.
content: Abigail Thernstrom, a social scientist whose colorblind remedies for racial disparities in educational achievement, voting and employment elevated her from a former red-diaper baby into a leading skeptic of affirmative action programs, died on April 10 in Arlington, Va. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Stop Airing Trump’s Briefings!
description: The media is allowing disinformation to appear as news.
content: Around this time four years ago, the media world was all abuzz over an analysis by mediaQuant, a company that tracks what is known as “earned media” coverage of political candidates. Earned media is free media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Abigail Thernstrom, Scholarly Foe of Affirmative Action, Dies at 83
description: She supported civil rights, but later, with her husband, Stephan, concluded that colorblind policies worked better than preferential treatment.
content: Abigail Thernstrom, a social scientist whose colorblind remedies for racial disparities in educational achievement, voting and employment elevated her from a former red-diaper baby into a leading skeptic of affirmative action programs, died on April 10 in Arlington, Va. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Single-Day Death Toll in N.Y. Dips Below 500
description: Deaths caused by the coronavirus have also been falling in New Jersey and Connecticut.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Monday that another 478 people had died in New York State, the lowest single-day toll in more than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye, Andrew Jacobs, Jo Becker and Tim Arango
title: Doctors and Governors Vie for Masks in Cloak-and-Dagger Deals
description: Despite plans to reopen states, equipment to protect workers from the coronavirus remains in high demand. “The need for an organized, equitable distribution system is dire,” a doctor said.
content: It was a stealth transaction, arranged through “someone who knew someone who knew someone,” taking place at an undisclosed location in an unnamed mid-Atlantic state. The getaway vehicles were disguised as food service delivery trucks, and they mapped out separate routes back to Massachusetts to avoid detection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Matthew Goldstein and Jeanna Smialek
title: Excluded From Bailouts, Mortgage Servicers Face Cash Crunch
description: Lawmakers and lobbyists warn that missed house payments could leave servicers insolvent but federal officials are not sold on the need for a rescue.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal policymakers have rushed to backstop nearly every corner of the financial system as the coronavirus exacts a bruising toll on the U.S. economy. But there is growing concern that a critical corner of the housing industry has been overlooked, putting mortgage companies in a precarious position as millions of borrowers delay payments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Landowners in Montana Superfund Fight
description: Landowners may not sue the Atlantic Richfield Company to force it to do more than a federal cleanup plan requires unless the Environmental Protection Agency consents, the court ruled.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court dealt a setback on Monday to roughly 100 Montana residents who sought to sue Atlantic Richfield Company to help them restore property contaminated by arsenic and lead.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Next Year (or Two) of the Pandemic
description: Immunity passports. Stop-start lockdowns. Strategic self-infection. This is what our new normal might look like.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: On Politics: Help for Small Businesses
description: A $450 billion bill would include money for hospitals and testing: This is your morning tip sheet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisha Cooper
title: Running Toward a New World
description: Masks, bandannas, dogs and distance make up the landscape of exercise in New York City.
content: The Boston Marathon will not take place on Monday. The London Marathon isn’t happening in a few days, either. The race calendar — from world majors to 5-kilometer fun runs — has been disrupted during the coronavirus pandemic. But the nation’s runners are out, adapting to a new world and continuing to put one foot in front of the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Libbey
title: A City Ballet Season, but Online, With Bells and Whistles
description: The company will stream video of performances and offer movement classes for adults and children.
content: Less than a month after canceling its spring season because of the coronavirus pandemic, New York City Ballet is back with a six-week slate of online programing. The company announced on Monday that it would broadcast full ballets and excerpts twice a week, from Tuesday through May 29, for free on its YouTube channel, Facebook page and website.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word + Quiz: marzipan
description: This word has appeared in 14 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Celebrating Literature’s Slacker Heroes, Idlers and Liers-In
description: Dwight Garner surveys the varied and glorious classic works on indolence.
content: Not everyone is having a bad lockdown. In The Spectator, the English weekly, Tom Stoppard wrote, “This is the life I’ve always wanted — social distancing without social disapproval.” Me? I’ve grown twitchy. The song I can’t stop listening to is Cab Calloway’s “I Gotta Go Places and Do Things.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: How Sports Adapt: A Marathon Indoors and Drive-In Soccer
description: German Silva used his race winnings to bring electricity to his hometown. Now, he’s running to honor the medical personnel on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: German Silva of Mexico came to fame — and nearly infamy — when he turned prematurely into Central Park in the final mile of the 1994 New York City Marathon, realized his mistake, backtracked and still pulled off a victory with a display of calm persistence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Climate Crash Course Part 6: Can insurance protect us?
description: From our climate crash course: When it comes to insurance in the age of climate change, there's good news and bad. But mostly, it's bad.
content: From our climate crash course: When it comes to insurance in the age of climate change, there's good news and bad. But mostly, it's bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate Crash Course Part 5: Do environmental rules matter?
description: Another installment of our climate crash course: understand how we entered the era of climate policy by executive order.
content: Another installment of our climate crash course: understand how we entered the era of climate policy by executive order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Smith
title: Richard Teitelbaum, Electronic Composer and Improviser, Dies at 80
description: Mr. Teitelbaum, whose sonic vocabulary emphasized otherworldly sounds and textures, worked with everyone from Karlheinz Stockhausen to Anthony Braxton.
content: Richard Teitelbaum, a composer and improviser widely admired in both contemporary classical and avant-garde jazz circles for his work with synthesizers and electronics, died on April 9 in Kingston, N.Y. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: New York Needed Ventilators. So They Developed One in a Month.
description: The pandemic inspired an innovative project to design and make a low-cost ventilator in weeks, not years.
content: The nudge came in an email in early March from an Italian friend alarmed by how fast the deadly coronavirus was spreading in his country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Is Michael Jordan Playing Defense in ‘The Last Dance’?
description: Jordan’s production company is a partner of the ESPN documentary, and the tone of the series so far bends toward reaffirming a legacy in the LeBron James era.
content: Michael Jordan seemingly has everything. He toppled almost all of his foes as a player. There was his individual greatness. Team greatness. Much business greatness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Can Investors Trust the Stock Market Rally?
description: After a swift rally, the market remains in limbo and investors are struggling to determine whether it’s a good time to buy stocks.
content: Less than a month ago, the stock market was in free fall, as a torrent of bad news about the coronavirus pandemic and its economic fallout drove investors to dump stocks. Just as swiftly, the market has rebounded, even as millions of people lose their jobs every week and the country is destined for a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Great Scented Candles, Recommended by T Editors
description: Suggestions for brightening your home — and filling it with fragrances that evoke faraway places.
content: During a time when many of us are compelled to remain within our homes, infusing a room with a fragrance, which has a famously powerful ability to evoke a specific place or memory, is one small way to help soothe frustrations and remind ourselves of the world beyond our walls. Here, T editors share the scented candles they’ve been burning lately, from a blend laced with Sicilian limes to one that evokes the Californian coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Michael Cooper
title: Georgia, Tennessee and South Carolina Say Businesses Can Reopen Soon
description: Even as some states move to restart their economies, coronavirus hot spots are emerging, including at a state prison in Ohio.
content: ATLANTA — Residents of Georgia will be allowed on Friday to return to the gym and get haircuts, pedicures, massages and tattoos. Next Monday, they can dine again in restaurants and go to the movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ted Loos
title: Keep Calm and Draw Together
description: With assists from Shepard Fairey and Maira Kalman, graphic designers and illustrators are creating striking visual messages of safety and gratitude.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic reshapes huge swaths of society, the design world is responding by doing what it does best: grabbing our attention with striking images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Henry Grimes and Giuseppi Logan, Lost and Found Jazz Stars, Are Both Gone
description: The musicians were the two biggest disappearing acts on the jazz avant-garde. Now both have died of complications of the coronavirus.
content: The lives of Henry Grimes and Giuseppi Logan already felt like the stuff of legend long before they came to an end last week — just two days and one borough apart — from complications of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Nina Balducci, Who Shaped a Famed Grocery Store, Dies at 91
description: She gave Balducci’s its polish and weathered an operatic family battle over the store’s ownership.
content: If you grew up as part of Nina Balducci’s clan, the rhythm of the week was set by meals orchestrated with equal parts panache and tradition. Friday night supper, in keeping with her Roman Catholic faith, was fish. Saturday was steak night. Sunday was pasta and red sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Kessler
title: We Need a New Social Contract for the Coronavirus
description: Our collective behavior will be the primary determinant of whether we can keep this virus in check.
content: Everyone wants to get back to work, school and together again as soon as possible. On Friday, the Trump administration announced it wants to do that in phases and allow each governor to make the decision when and how to reopen. Even then, the virus will continue to lurk in people who are unaware they are carrying and spreading it to others who will become ill with Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marco Rubio
title: We Need a More Resilient American Economy
description: With a sensible industrial policy, workers will take precedence over short-term corporate gain.
content: Americans are a resilient people. We persevere through difficult circumstances and arrive triumphant on the other side of adversity. It’s in our national DNA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Issi Romem
title: A Cheaper Roof Over Your Head During the Pandemic?
description: A relatively new arrangement, combining the advantages of renting and buying, could help people keep their homes and help millennials enter the housing market. But hidden within that idea is a danger.
content: We take for granted that homes are either owned or rented, but that could soon change, and pandemic-driven economic pain could accelerate the process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Bans Non-Unanimous Jury Verdicts for Serious Crimes
description: The badly fractured decision, affecting defendants in two states, continued a debate among the justices over the power of precedent.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that the Constitution banned non-unanimous jury verdicts in cases involving serious crimes. The decision will affect defendants and prisoners in Louisiana and Oregon, the only two states that have allowed such verdicts in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mariel Padilla
title: Michelle Obama Is Reading Books to Children Stuck at Home
description: The former first lady said she would share some of her favorite children’s books and try to give families a much-needed break.
content: Michelle Obama read one of her beloved children’s books aloud on Monday, live streaming to hundreds of thousands of people stuck at home. The virtual story time was the first in a four-week series called “Mondays with Michelle Obama.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: Climate Crash Course Part 6: Can insurance protect us?
description: From our climate crash course: When it comes to insurance in the age of climate change, there's good news and bad. But mostly, it's bad.
content: From our climate crash course: When it comes to insurance in the age of climate change, there's good news and bad. But mostly, it's bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Climate Crash Course Part 3: Who is influencing key decisions?
description: Hiroko Tabuchi, an investigative reporter for the Times Climate desk, explains how following a money trail helps explain “who’s asking for what, and who’s getting what they want.”
content: Hiroko Tabuchi, an investigative reporter for the Times Climate desk, explains how following a money trail helps explain “who’s asking for what, and who’s getting what they want.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate Crash Course Part 5: Do environmental rules matter?
description: Another installment of our climate crash course: understand how we entered the era of climate policy by executive order.
content: Another installment of our climate crash course: understand how we entered the era of climate policy by executive order.
source.name: The New York Times

title: U.S. Oil Prices Plunge Into Negative Territory: Live Markets Updates
description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
content: Something bizarre happened in the oil markets on Monday: Prices fell so much that some traders paid buyers to take oil off their hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Grady
title: The Pandemic’s Hidden Victims: Sick or Dying, but Not From the Virus
description: As the coronavirus overwhelms the health care system, people with other illnesses struggle to find treatment.
content: Maria Kefalas considers her husband, Patrick Carr, a forgotten victim of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger
title: ‘It’s Really a Gift’: Israeli Hospitals Let Relatives Say Goodbye Up Close
description: A hospital spokesman asked why family members were barred from coronavirus wards when journalists could visit in protective gear. His bosses had no good answer.
content: JERUSALEM — A few people had already died alone of the coronavirus at Tel Aviv’s Sourasky Medical Center when the hospital spokesman put to his bosses a question that had been gnawing at him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: In Old Cairo, a Subdued Ramadan Looms as Virus Shutters the City
description: The holiest month in the Islamic calendar promises this year to be the strangest ever for the world’s 1.8 billion Muslims. In Cairo, known as the city of a thousand minarets, the coronavirus has cast a long shadow.
content: CAIRO — For over a thousand years, Cairo’s oldest mosques kept their doors open — through the Black Death of the 14th century, the devastating cholera epidemics of the 19th century and the Spanish flu in the winter of 1918 that claimed 140,000 Egyptian lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson and David S. Allee
title: Showtime, Suspended
description: Broadway was booming. Then the coronavirus turned New York’s theater district into a ghost town.
content: One month after Broadway shut down, I decided to take a walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Can Investors Trust the Stock Market Rally?
description: After a swift rally, the market remains in limbo and investors are struggling to determine whether it’s a good time to buy stocks.
content: Less than a month ago, the stock market was in free fall, as a torrent of bad news about the coronavirus pandemic and its economic fallout drove investors to dump stocks. Just as swiftly, the market has rebounded, even as millions of people lose their jobs every week and the country is destined for a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Is Michael Jordan Playing Defense in ‘The Last Dance’?
description: Jordan’s production company is a partner of the ESPN documentary, and the tone of the series so far bends toward reaffirming a legacy in the LeBron James era.
content: Michael Jordan seemingly has everything. He toppled almost all of his foes as a player. There was his individual greatness. Team greatness. Much business greatness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker
title: Two E.R. Workers Worry: If They Died, Who’d Take Care of Their Son?
description: A couple who both work in New York City public hospitals are facing unimagined strain as they fight the coronavirus pandemic.
content: A few nights ago, after their 18-month-old son, Nolan, went to sleep, Dr. Adam Hill and Neena Budhraja sat down on the living room couch in their apartment in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Pen and paper in hand, they turned their attention to a pressing need: figuring out who would be Nolan’s legal guardian if the coronavirus swept them away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisha Cooper
title: Running Toward a New World
description: Masks, bandannas, dogs and distance make up the landscape of exercise in New York City.
content: The Boston Marathon will not take place on Monday. The London Marathon isn’t happening in a few days, either. The race calendar — from world majors to 5-kilometer fun runs — has been disrupted during the coronavirus pandemic. But the nation’s runners are out, adapting to a new world and continuing to put one foot in front of the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: How Coronavirus Infected Some, but Not All, in a Restaurant
description: A limited study by Chinese researchers suggests the role played by air currents in spreading the illness in enclosed spaces.
content: In January, at a restaurant in Guangzhou, China, one diner infected with the novel coronavirus but not yet feeling sick appeared to have spread the disease to nine other people. One of the restaurant’s air-conditioners apparently blew the virus particles around the dining room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: DC to Resume Sales of Some New Comic Books
description: The publishing home of Batman and Superman will sell some new comics to stores starting next week.
content: After an absence of nearly a month, some costumed superheroes are planning to return to the pages of  comic books and to the stores that can still sell them.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Original Earth Day
description: Read The New York Times’s coverage of the inaugural Earth Day in 1970.
content: Read The New York Times’s coverage of the inaugural Earth Day in 1970.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Youth Sports Worry About Weathering Pandemic, and Future Play
description: Will parents and children be eager to return to team sports once the threat of the coronavirus outbreak has passed?
content: It was supposed to be a profitable spring for Trilogy Lacrosse. Its spring break training camps held in Arizona and Nevada for high school teams were sold out. So was its youth tournament at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey, scheduled for the last Sunday in March. The company, founded by a band of former college all-Americans, hoped to celebrate its 15th year in operation in style this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Madeleine Albright Thinks It’s Good When America Gets Involved
description: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”
content: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Does the Pressure of a Pandemic Transform a Cellist’s Bach?
description: Alisa Weilerstein is streaming one movement of the Bach cello suites a day, just as she has released a polished studio recording of them.
content: Back we go to Bach. Musicians everywhere seem to be turning to his music as the soundtrack of despair and hope, for both private solace and public streams.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: The World of (No) Sports
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 20, 2020.
content: “I stand in the hall at the top of the stairs and I have one foot in the bathroom and one in the hall. So if someone needs to go to the bathroom I can’t throw.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Roberts
title: This Earth Day, We Should Repent
description: It’s time to consider a new kind of declaration. A declaration of responsibility.
content: Wednesday is Earth Day, a useful idea that could only occur to a civilization estranged from Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kuttner
title: What America Can Do to Fight Mass Unemployment
description: The vital agencies that support employment and loans need reinforcing.
content: Years of bashing by anti-government ideologues have gutted the capacity of vital agencies like the I.R.S., the Small Business Administration and state unemployment offices. In the economic calamity brought on by the pandemic, in the past month alone, over 22 million jobless Americans have filed for relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Roberts
title: This Earth Day, We Should Repent
description: It’s time to consider a new kind of declaration. A declaration of responsibility.
content: Wednesday is Earth Day, a useful idea that could only occur to a civilization estranged from Earth.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: When Did We Start Taking Famous People Seriously?
description: Actors are giving us advice on parenting and politics — and vaccines?
content: This article was originally published on June 20, 2019 in NYT Parenting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: How to Make One-Pot Pasta With Practically Any Pasta
description: Master this technique, and save yourself time at the stove — and the sink.
content: There’s one thing you can do to make any pasta dish easier, and arguably more satisfying: Cook the pasta and the sauce together in a single pot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Madeleine Albright Thinks It’s Good When America Gets Involved
description: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”
content: “Democracy has to deliver. People have to recognize that other people not only want to vote but they want to eat.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: 7 Reasons We Can’t Yet Reopen America
description: We’re making progress, but not nearly enough.
content: This article is part of David Leonhardt’s newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it each weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Coronavirus, Spain’s Children, Antibodies: Your Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Climate Crash Course Part 7: Is what I do important?
description: Closing out our crash course in climate issues: Personal actions and international cooperation are inextricably linked, but don't forget that the future isn’t set in stone.
content: Closing out our crash course in climate issues: Personal actions and international cooperation are inextricably linked, but don't forget that the future isn’t set in stone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Halpert
title: How to Manage Your Loneliness
description: You are far from alone in feeling alone. Here are some ideas to help.
content: Shelter-in-place orders have hit those who live alone particularly hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Businesses Say Big Banks Flouted ‘First Come First Served’ for Aid
description: Small-business owners are suing, claiming that applications for stimulus loans weren’t processed in the order they were received.
content: Small-business owners have accused some of the country’s largest banks of unfairly favoring applications from their wealthiest clients for aid under a $349 billion government stimulus program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: ‘I Don’t Think the New York That We Left Will Be Back for Some Years’
description: The features that made the city’s economy distinctive — Broadway, restaurants and museums — were hard hit and will take the longest to come back.
content: It took just a matter of days to shut down New York City, once the coronavirus took hold. Restarting it will take much, much longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Easing lockdowns in Australia and New Zealand, a spike in cases in Singapore and plummeting U.S. oil prices.
content: Surfers returned to a few beaches in Sydney on Monday, and children in New Zealand will return to school in a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane L. Levere
title: Business Travel Has Stopped. No One Knows When It Will Come Back.
description: But one thing is certain: It will be changed. Airports, airlines and hotels will be taking new precautions, experts predict. And conferences will eventually return.
content: Business travel worldwide has basically come to a standstill in the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Singer and Nicole Perlroth
title: Zoom’s Security Woes Were No Secret to Business Partners Like Dropbox
description: Dropbox privately paid top hackers to find bugs in software by the videoconferencing company Zoom, then pressed it to fix them.
content: One year ago, two Australian hackers found themselves on an eight-hour flight to Singapore to attend a live hacking competition sponsored by Dropbox. At 30,000 feet, with nothing but a slow internet connection, they decided to get a head start by hacking Zoom, a videoconferencing service that they knew was used by many Dropbox employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Australia Moves to Force Google and Facebook to Compensate Media Outlets
description: The decision, announced after talks on a voluntary system stalled, is part of a global push to save local news organizations.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Australian government said on Monday that Google and Facebook would have to pay media outlets for news content in the country, part of an emerging global effort to rescue local publishers by moving to compel tech giants to share their advertising revenue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss
title: Too Much Oil: How a Barrel Came to Be Worth Less Than Nothing
description: One oil price went negative on Monday, signaling that there is no place to store all the crude the world is producing but not using.
content: Something bizarre happened in the oil markets on Monday: Prices fell so much that some traders paid buyers to take oil off their hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu’s Power Is Extended as Rival Accepts Israel Unity Government
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, an embattled political survivor, persuaded Benny Gantz to join forces with him to combat the coronavirus.
content: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and his former challenger, Benny Gantz, agreed Monday night to establish a unity government, a deal that finally breaks a yearlong political impasse and keeps Mr. Netanyahu in office as he faces trial on corruption charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: At Least 2 Dead as Severe Weather Sweeps Through the South
description: A 61-year-old man was killed in Alabama after his mobile home tumbled over, and one person died in Mississippi, officials said. Florida, Georgia and the Carolinas were in the path of strong storms on Monday.
content: At least two people died after severe weather brought hail and storms through Alabama, Mississippi and other Southern states on Sunday and Monday, the second consecutive weekend that dangerous storms swept through the region.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cancel the Trump TV Show
description: A reader says the daily briefings cause more harm than good. Also: Acts of kindness, everywhere; Joe Biden’s choice of running mate.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: NPR Cuts Executive Pay as Corporate Sponsors’ Payments Fall
description: The chief executive of the radio and podcasting giant said he hoped to avoid layoffs.
content: National Public Radio, the purveyor of “Morning Edition,” “All Things Considered” and “Planet Money,” is cutting executives’ pay to combat the effects of the economic collapse brought on by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Sirio Maccioni, Whose Le Cirque Drew Manhattan’s Elite, Dies at 88
description: Dash, charm and matinee-idol looks helped make Mr. Maccioni an unusual sort of celebrity in New York City’s restaurant scene.
content: Sirio Maccioni, a Manhattan restaurateur who made Le Cirque a headquarters for Manhattan’s rich and powerful in the 1980s and ’90s, and put dishes like pasta primavera and crème brûlée on the culinary map, died on Monday in the town where he was born, Montecatini, in Tuscany, Italy. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Death Toll Soars in Turkey; W.H.O. Warns of Vaccine Roadblock
description: Singapore, an early success story, is having a surge in cases, while European countries start to ease restrictions. Oil prices nosedived as a worldwide surplus grew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: ‘The Big Guys Get Bailed Out’: Restaurants Vie for Relief Funds
description: Shake Shack was among the larger companies criticized for seeking small-business emergency loans from the federal government.
content: Buried deep in the 900-page stimulus package that Congress passed in March, a single paragraph has sparked an outcry from small restaurants as major chains and mom-and-pop places alike scramble to survive a devastating financial crisis.
source.name: The New York Times
